message_1: What is the intersection cohomology group of the singular quadric surface given by the equation $x^2+y^2-z^2=0$?
message_2:
The singular quadric surface given by the equation $x^2 + y^2 - z^2 = 0$ is a cone in $\mathbb{P}^3$. To compute its intersection cohomology groups, we can use the Lefschetz Hyperplane Theorem and the fact that the intersection cohomology groups of a smooth quadric surface are isomorphic to the cohomology groups of the corresponding projective space.

Let $Q$ be the smooth quadric surface in $\mathbb{P}^3$ given by the equation $x^2 + y^2 - z^2 - w^2 = 0$. Then the intersection cohomology groups of $Q$ are given by:

$$IH^i(Q) = \begin{cases}
\mathbb{Z} & \text{if } i = 0, 2, 4 \\
0 & \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}$$

Now, let $C$ be the singular quadric cone given by the equation $x^2 + y^2 - z^2 = 0$. We can think of $C$ as the intersection of $Q$ with the hyperplane $w = 0$. By the Lefschetz Hyperplane Theorem, the intersection cohomology groups of $C$ are isomorphic to the cohomology groups of $Q$ in degrees less than 4. Therefore, we have:

$$IH^i(C) = \begin{cases}
\mathbb{Z} & \text{if } i = 0, 2 \\
0 & \text{if } i = 1, 3 \\
IH^4(C) & \text{if } i = 4
\end{cases}$$

To compute $IH^4(C)$, we can use the long exact sequence in intersection cohomology associated to the pair $(Q, C)$. This sequence has the form:

$$\cdots \to IH^3(Q) \to IH^3(C) \to IH^4(Q \cap C) \to IH^4(Q) \to IH^4(C) \to \cdots$$

Since $IH^3(Q) = IH^3(C) = 0$, we have an isomorphism $IH^4(Q \cap C) \cong IH^4(Q)$. The intersection $Q \cap C$ is a smooth quadric curve in $\mathbb{P}^2$, so its cohomology groups are given by:

$$IH^i(Q \cap C) = \begin{cases}
\mathbb{Z} & \text{if } i = 0, 2 \\
0 & \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}$$

Thus, we have $IH^4(C) \cong \mathbb{Z}$. In summary, the intersection cohomology groups of the singular quadric surface $C$ are given by:

$$IH^i(C) = \begin{cases}
\mathbb{Z} & \text{if } i = 0, 2, 4 \\
0 & \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}$$
